# Recipe: Stovetop Shakshuka

- [Storage and Leftovers](#storage-and-leftovers)
- [Frequently Asked Questions](#frequently-asked-questions)

## Introduction
Shakshuka is a popular Middle Eastern dish made with eggs poached in a flavorful tomato and pepper sauce. It is a hearty and satisfying meal that can be enjoyed for breakfast, brunch, or even dinner. This stovetop version of Shakshuka is quick and easy to make, perfect for busy days when you want a delicious and nutritious meal.

## Ingredients
- 2 tablespoons olive oil
- 1 onion, diced
- 1 red bell pepper, diced
- 2 cloves garlic, minced
- 1 teaspoon cumin
- 1 teaspoon paprika
- 1/2 teaspoon chili powder (optional, for heat)
- 1 can (400g) crushed tomatoes
- Salt and pepper, to taste
- 4-6 large eggs
- Fresh parsley, chopped (for garnish)
- Crusty bread or pita, for serving

## Equipment
- Large skillet or frying pan with a lid
- Wooden spoon or spatula
- Knife and cutting board
- Measuring spoons

## Preparation Time
- 10 minutes

## Cooking Time
- 20 minutes

## Steps
1. Heat olive oil in a large skillet or frying pan over medium heat.
2. Add diced onions and bell peppers to the pan. Saut√© for 5 minutes until they start to soften.
3. Add minced garlic, cumin, paprika, and chili powder (if using). Cook for an additional 1-2 minutes until fragrant.
4. Pour in the crushed tomatoes and season with salt and pepper to taste. Stir well to combine all the ingredients.
5. Reduce the heat to low and let the sauce simmer for 10 minutes, allowing the flavors to meld together.
6. Create small wells in the sauce with a spoon and carefully crack the eggs into each well.
7. Cover the skillet with a lid and cook for about 5-7 minutes, or until the eggs are cooked to your desired level of doneness. For runny yolks, cook for less time, and for fully cooked yolks, cook for longer.
8. Once the eggs are cooked, remove the skillet from heat and garnish with freshly chopped parsley.
9. Serve the Shakshuka hot with crusty bread or pita on the side.

## Serving Suggestions
- Shakshuka is traditionally served with crusty bread or pita, which is perfect for dipping into the flavorful sauce and scooping up the eggs.
- You can also serve it with a side salad or a dollop of yogurt for added freshness and creaminess.

## Variations
- Add some crumbled feta cheese or goat cheese on top of the Shakshuka for a tangy and creamy twist.
- For a spicier version, add a chopped jalapeno or a pinch of red pepper flakes to the sauce.
- Feel free to add other vegetables like zucchini, spinach, or mushrooms to the sauce for extra flavor and nutrition.

## Tips and Tricks
- Make sure to use a skillet or frying pan with a lid to properly cook the eggs.
- Adjust the spices according to your taste preferences. Add more chili powder if you like it spicy or omit it if you prefer a milder flavor.
- Don't overcook the eggs if you want a runny yolk. Keep an eye on them and remove the skillet from heat as soon as they reach your desired level of doneness.

## Nutritional Information
- The nutritional information for this recipe may vary depending on the specific ingredients used. Here is a general breakdown per serving (without bread):
  - Calories: 180
  - Fat: 12g
  - Carbohydrates: 12g
  - Protein: 8g
  - Fiber: 3g

## Storage and Leftovers
- Shakshuka is best enjoyed fresh, but any leftovers can be stored in an airtight container in the refrigerator for up to 2 days. Reheat gently on the stovetop or in the microwave before serving.

## Frequently Asked Questions
- Q: Can I make Shakshuka ahead of time?
  - A: While it's best to enjoy Shakshuka fresh, you can prepare the sauce ahead of time and store it in the refrigerator for up to 2 days. When ready to serve, reheat the sauce and proceed with adding the eggs.

- Q: Can I use whole tomatoes instead of crushed tomatoes?
  - A: Yes, you can use whole tomatoes and crush them yourself using a fork or a blender. Adjust the cooking time accordingly to allow the sauce to thicken.

- Q: Can I make Shakshuka without eggs?
  - A: Yes, you can make a vegan version of Shakshuka by substituting the eggs with tofu or chickpeas. Adjust the cooking time accordingly to cook the tofu or chickpeas through.

- Q: Can I freeze Shakshuka?
  - A: It is not recommended to freeze Shakshuka as the texture of the eggs may change upon thawing and reheating. It is best enjoyed fresh or stored in the refrigerator for a few days.
